December 10, 1953
Dra Harry J» Skornia, Executive Director
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
14 Gregory Hall
University of Illinois
Urbana, Illinois
Dear Harry:
This is in connection with Larry Creshkoff’s letter to you of
October 8. If it is true that Larry actually ©epeets to have kadiodiffusion
Francaise insert English explanations at frequent intervals, e.g., between
acts and scenes, WGBH either will have to cut the English or be denied the
opportunity to use the plays*
Exactly the same principle applies in attempting to teach an audience
in the intermission commentary of a Symphony concert when it does not know
music, as in attempting to teach an audience what a French play is all about
by the suggested omraentaries in English. The suggestion seems to me an
offense to the people who can benefit from the unity, movement and integrity
of a French play in French*
I believe tnere is plenty of evidence to support this view and I know
of none to support its opposite. Either you can understand enough French to
follow the play or you cannot, but if you cannot, you will learn more by
listening to the real thing than to a hashed-up version. An advance pre¬
paration course like the one fciGBH does for the Boston Symphony Orchestra con¬
certs might be appropriate. Both Dr. William N. Lock©, Professor of Modern
Languages and in charge of the Department of Modern Languages at Massachusetts
Institute of Technology and Professor Marston S. Balch of Tufts College agree
that after the plays have begun, they should continue without interruption.
Both of these men have given introductory remarks in English proceeding our
broadcasts of Comedie Francaise plays. I am enclosing copies of listener
letters received by WGBH in the last six weeks which reflect a i*eal apprecia¬
tion of the opportunity to hear the Comedie Francaise as one might hear it
in Paris.
Either let us put on the plays in French or put them on in English
translation, We want them in French not because of Boston but because of
every good reason which is equally applicable in Ames, Madison, Minneapolis,
University City, or Houston.
